payload.instructions:
# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
Source code lives in `src`. Routes and layouts use the App Router under `src/app`, with segment folders like `src/app/[lineId]` for dynamic pages and `src/app/api` for server handlers. Reusable UI sits in `src/components`, while feature-specific logic is grouped inside `src/features/<feature>`. Shared hooks (`src/hooks`), database helpers (`src/lib`), and design tokens (`src/styles`) keep cross-cutting concerns centralized. Static assets (logos, favicons) belong in `public`. Keep new modules aligned with this layout so imports remain predictable.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- `npm run dev`: Launches the Next.js dev server with React Fast Refresh.
- `npm run build`: Produces an optimized production bundle; run before deploys.
- `npm run start`: Serves the latest build locally for smoke-testing production output.
- `npm run lint`: Executes the project-wide ESLint rules (Next.js core-web-vitals baseline). Treat warnings as errors before opening a PR.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
Use modern ES modules with functional React components. Prefer two-space indentation and trailing commas, matching the existing files. Components that render UI should use PascalCase filenames (`ThemeToggle.jsx`), hooks use camelCase prefixed with `use` (`use-mobile.js`), and utility modules go in `src/lib` with hyphenated names. Favor Tailwind classes for styling; co-locate any component-specific CSS in `src/styles` only if a utility class will not suffice. Run `npm run lint` to ensure ESLint (configured in `eslint.config.mjs`) flags accessibility and performance regressions early.

## Testing Guidelines
Automated tests are not yet wired in. When adding them, group specs beside their feature (`src/features/navigation/__tests__/NavMenu.test.jsx`) so intent is obvious. Name files with `.test.jsx` or `.test.js`. For critical flows lacking automation, document manual verification steps in the PR description and exercise them against `npm run start` output. Keep database interactions mocked or pointed at disposable fixtures to avoid mutating shared environments.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
Craft commit subjects in the imperative mood (“Add navigation badges”), roughly 50 characters, with optional detail in the body. Combine related changes rather than batching multiple features. Pull requests should include: a concise summary, linked issue IDs, screenshots or clip recordings for UI changes, and notes on testing performed (`npm run lint`, manual checks, etc.). Request reviews from owners of affected areas (`src/features/<feature>` or shared libs) before merging.

## Environment & Configuration Tips
Local MySQL connectivity is managed via `src/lib/db.js`, which reads `DB_HOST`, `DB_PORT`, `DB_USER`, `DB_PASSWORD`, and `DB_NAME`. Place secrets in `.env.local`; never commit credentials. Tailwind configuration is defined through `components.json` and `postcss.config.mjs`. If you introduce new design tokens, update `src/styles/tokens.css` and keep class names consistent with Tailwind’s utility-first approach.

content.text:
# AGENTS.md instructions for /home/pjw75/tailwind

<INSTRUCTIONS>
# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
Source code lives in `src`. Routes and layouts use the App Router under `src/app`, with segment folders like `src/app/[lineId]` for dynamic pages and `src/app/api` for server handlers. Reusable UI sits in `src/components`, while feature-specific logic is grouped inside `src/features/<feature>`. Shared hooks (`src/hooks`), database helpers (`src/lib`), and design tokens (`src/styles`) keep cross-cutting concerns centralized. Static assets (logos, favicons) belong in `public`. Keep new modules aligned with this layout so imports remain predictable.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- `npm run dev`: Launches the Next.js dev server with React Fast Refresh.
- `npm run build`: Produces an optimized production bundle; run before deploys.
- `npm run start`: Serves the latest build locally for smoke-testing production output.
- `npm run lint`: Executes the project-wide ESLint rules (Next.js core-web-vitals baseline). Treat warnings as errors before opening a PR.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
Use modern ES modules with functional React components. Prefer two-space indentation and trailing commas, matching the existing files. Components that render UI should use PascalCase filenames (`ThemeToggle.jsx`), hooks use camelCase prefixed with `use` (`use-mobile.js`), and utility modules go in `src/lib` with hyphenated names. Favor Tailwind classes for styling; co-locate any component-specific CSS in `src/styles` only if a utility class will not suffice. Run `npm run lint` to ensure ESLint (configured in `eslint.config.mjs`) flags accessibility and performance regressions early.

## Testing Guidelines
Automated tests are not yet wired in. When adding them, group specs beside their feature (`src/features/navigation/__tests__/NavMenu.test.jsx`) so intent is obvious. Name files with `.test.jsx` or `.test.js`. For critical flows lacking automation, document manual verification steps in the PR description and exercise them against `npm run start` output. Keep database interactions mocked or pointed at disposable fixtures to avoid mutating shared environments.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
Craft commit subjects in the imperative mood (“Add navigation badges”), roughly 50 characters, with optional detail in the body. Combine related changes rather than batching multiple features. Pull requests should include: a concise summary, linked issue IDs, screenshots or clip recordings for UI changes, and notes on testing performed (`npm run lint`, manual checks, etc.). Request reviews from owners of affected areas (`src/features/<feature>` or shared libs) before merging.

## Environment & Configuration Tips
Local MySQL connectivity is managed via `src/lib/db.js`, which reads `DB_HOST`, `DB_PORT`, `DB_USER`, `DB_PASSWORD`, and `DB_NAME`. Place secrets in `.env.local`; never commit credentials. Tailwind configuration is defined through `components.json` and `postcss.config.mjs`. If you introduce new design tokens, update `src/styles/tokens.css` and keep class names consistent with Tailwind’s utility-first approach.

</INSTRUCTIONS>

payload.text:
**Designing hover label and value update**

I’m figuring out how to show the pie chart’s label and value in the center when hovering over slices by adding React state to track the active slice. My plan includes hooking mouse events on the Pie component to update this state and conditionally rendering the label and value inside the center label, replacing the total during hover. I’ll also clear the hovered state when data changes to keep it in sync. This approach should meet the task of displaying label and value on mouse hover in a straightforward way!

summary.text:
**Designing hover label and value update**

I’m figuring out how to show the pie chart’s label and value in the center when hovering over slices by adding React state to track the active slice. My plan includes hooking mouse events on the Pie component to update this state and conditionally rendering the label and value inside the center label, replacing the total during hover. I’ll also clear the hovered state when data changes to keep it in sync. This approach should meet the task of displaying label and value on mouse hover in a straightforward way!

payload.name: apply_patch

payload.output: {"output":"Success. Updated the following files:\nM apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/StatusDistributionCard.jsx\n","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.0}}

payload.message:
- Added hover state tracking on the pie slices so the center label now switches from the total to the hovered slice’s label and formatted row count, giving the requested “label + value on hover” behavior (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/StatusDistributionCard.jsx:1-73`).
- Reset the hover state whenever the backing `data` set changes to avoid stale labels (`StatusDistributionCard.jsx:12-22`).

Consider running `npm run web:dev` (or your preferred preview flow) to visually confirm the interaction.

content.text:
- Added hover state tracking on the pie slices so the center label now switches from the total to the hovered slice’s label and formatted row count, giving the requested “label + value on hover” behavior (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/StatusDistributionCard.jsx:1-73`).
- Reset the hover state whenever the backing `data` set changes to avoid stale labels (`StatusDistributionCard.jsx:12-22`).

Consider running `npm run web:dev` (or your preferred preview flow) to visually confirm the interaction.

payload.message:
- Hovering a slice now updates the center label to show that slice’s name and formatted value, falling back to the total rows when nothing is hovered (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/StatusDistributionCard.jsx:1-68`).
- Removed the Recharts tooltip entirely so the popup no longer shows; the hover feedback is now centralized in the pie’s label (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/StatusDistributionCard.jsx:5-51`).

Run `npm run web:dev` to confirm the interaction looks right in the browser.

content.text:
- Hovering a slice now updates the center label to show that slice’s name and formatted value, falling back to the total rows when nothing is hovered (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/StatusDistributionCard.jsx:1-68`).
- Removed the Recharts tooltip entirely so the popup no longer shows; the hover feedback is now centralized in the pie’s label (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/StatusDistributionCard.jsx:5-51`).

Run `npm run web:dev` to confirm the interaction looks right in the browser.

@@
 const QUICK_FILTER_DEFINITIONS = [
@@

     key: "sdwt_prod",
     label: "설비분임조",
@@
     compareOptions: (a, b) => a.label.localeCompare(b.label, undefined, { sensitivity: "base" }),
   },
+  {
+    key: "main_step",
+    label: "Main Step",
+    resolveColumn: (columns) => findMatchingColumn(columns, "main_step"),
+    normalizeValue: (value) => {
+      if (value == null) return null
+      const normalized = String(value).trim()
+      return normalized.length > 0 ? normalized : null
+    },
+    formatValue: (value) => value,
+    compareOptions: (a, b) => a.label.localeCompare(b.label, undefined, { sensitivity: "base" }),
+  },
   {
     key: "user_sdwt_prod",
     label: "Engr분임조",
*** End Patch

payload.output: Plan updated

{"output":"     1	// src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/filters/quickFilters.js
     2	// 퀵 필터 섹션을 생성하고 적용하는 로직입니다.
     3	import { STATUS_LABELS, STATUS_SEQUENCE } from "../../../constants/status-labels"
     4	
     5	const STATUS_ORDER = STATUS_SEQUENCE
     6	const STATUS_ORDER_INDEX = new Map(STATUS_ORDER.map((status, index) => [status, index]))
     7	
     8	const MULTI_SELECT_KEYS = new Set(["status"])
     9	
    10	const HOUR_IN_MS = 60 * 60 * 1000
    11	const FUTURE_TOLERANCE_MS = 5 * 60 * 1000
    12	
    13	const RECENT_HOUR_OPTIONS = [
    14	  { value: "12", label: "~12시간" },
    15	  { value: "24", label: "~24시간" },
    16	  { value: "36", label: "~36시간" },
    17	]
    18	
    19	function findMatchingColumn(columns, target) {
    20	  if (!Array.isArray(columns)) return null
    21	  const targetLower = target.toLowerCase()
    22	  return (
    23	    columns.find((column) => typeof column === "string" && column.toLowerCase() === targetLower) ??
    24	    null
    25	  )
    26	}
    27	
    28	function normalizeBooleanValue(value) {
    29	  if (typeof value === "boolean") return value
    30	  if (value === null || value === undefined) return null
    31	  if (typeof value === "number" && Number.isFinite(value)) {
    32	    if (value === 1) return true
    33	    if (value === 0) return false
    34	    return null
    35	  }
    36	  if (typeof value === "string") {
    37	    const normalized = value.trim().toLowerCase()
    38	    if (!normalized) return null
    39	    if (["1", "true", "t", "y", "yes"].includes(normalized)) return true
    40	    if (["0", "false", "f", "n", "no"].includes(normalized)) return false
    41	    return null
    42	  }
    43	  if (typeof value === "bigint") {
    44	    if (value === 1n) return true
    45	    if (value === 0n) return false
    46	  }
    47	  return null
    48	}
    49	
    50	function toTimestamp(value) {
    51	  if (value == null) return null
    52	
    53	  if (value instanceof Date) {
    54	    const time = value.getTime()
    55	    return Number.isNaN(time) ? null : time
    56	  }
    57	
    58	  if (typeof value === "number") {
    59	    return Number.isFinite(value) ? value : null
    60	  }
    61	
    62	  if (typeof value === "string") {
    63	    const trimmed = value.trim()
    64	    if (trimmed.length === 0) return null
    65	
    66	    const numeric = Number(trimmed)
    67	    if (Number.isFinite(numeric)) {
    68	      return numeric
    69	    }
    70	
    71	    const parsed = new Date(trimmed)
    72	    const time = parsed.getTime()
    73	    return Number.isNaN(time) ? null : time
    74	  }
    75	
    76	  const parsed = new Date(value)
    77	  const time = parsed.getTime()
    78	  return Number.isNaN(time) ? null : time
    79	}
    80	
    81	const QUICK_FILTER_DEFINITIONS = [
    82	  {
    83	    key: "recent_hours",
    84	    label: "최근시간",
    85	    resolveColumn: (columns) =>
    86	      findMatchingColumn(columns, "created_at") ?? findMatchingColumn(columns, "updated_at"),
    87	    buildSection: ({ columns }) => {
    88	      const columnKey =
    89	        findMatchingColumn(columns, "created_at") ?? findMatchingColumn(columns, "updated_at")
    90	      if (!columnKey) return null
    91	
    92	      const getValue = (row) => row?.[columnKey] ?? null
    93	
    94	      return {
    95	        options: RECENT_HOUR_OPTIONS.map((option) => ({ ...option })),
    96	        getValue,
    97	        matchRow: (row, current) => {
    98	          if (current === null) return true
    99	
   100	          const hours = Number(current)
   101	          if (!Number.isFinite(hours) || hours <= 0) return true
   102	
   103	          const timestamp = toTimestamp(getValue(row))
   104	          if (timestamp === null) return false
   105	
   106	          const now = Date.now()
   107	          const minTimestamp = now - hours * HOUR_IN_MS
   108	          const maxTimestamp = now + FUTURE_TOLERANCE_MS
   109	
   110	          return timestamp >= minTimestamp && timestamp <= maxTimestamp
   111	        },
   112	      }
   113	    },
   114	  },
   115	  {
   116	    key: "status",
   117	    label: "Status",
   118	    resolveColumn: (columns) => findMatchingColumn(columns, "status"),
   119	    normalizeValue: (value) => {
   120	      if (value == null) return null
   121	      const normalized = String(value).trim()
   122	      return normalized.length > 0 ? normalized.toUpperCase() : null
   123	    },
   124	    formatValue: (value) => STATUS_LABELS[value] ?? value,
   125	    compareOptions: (a, b) => {
   126	      const indexA = STATUS_ORDER_INDEX.has(a.value)
   127	        ? STATUS_ORDER_INDEX.get(a.value)
   128	        : Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY
   129	      const indexB = STATUS_ORDER_INDEX.has(b.value)
   130	        ? STATUS_ORDER_INDEX.get(b.value)
   131	        : Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY
   132	      if (indexA !== indexB) return indexA - indexB
   133	      return a.label.localeCompare(b.label, undefined, { sensitivity: "base" })
   134	    },
   135	  },
   136	  {
   137	    key: "needtosend",
   138	    label: "예약",
   139	    resolveColumn: (columns) => findMatchingColumn(columns, "needtosend"),
   140	    normalizeValue: normalizeBooleanValue,
   141	    formatValue: (value) => (value ? "Yes" : "No"),
   142	    compareOptions: (a, b) => {
   143	      if (a.value === b.value) return 0
   144	      if (a.value === true) return -1
   145	      if (b.value === true) return 1
   146	      return 0
   147	    },
   148	  },
   149	  {

payload.message:
- Added a `main_step` quick filter definition so the dropdown options are populated from the hidden `main_step` column values and still filter the backing rows (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/filters/quickFilters.js:1-214`).
- Registered `main_step` as a dropdown-based quick filter so it renders alongside the existing select inputs with the same UX (`apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/components/data-table/filters/QuickFilters.jsx:1-190`).

I didn’t rerun the app or lint due to the small scoped change; consider `npm run web:dev` to confirm the new dropdown behaves correctly.

payload.message:
- Updated the dark theme token set so the shared `--background`, `--card`, `--popover`, and sidebar-related variables all use a true black base (`apps/web/src/styles/tokens.css:79-126`). This makes every dark-mode surface start from pure black while keeping existing foreground, accent, and chart colors intact.

Consider running `npm run web:dev` to preview the new contrast and tweak secondary tones if needed.

content.text:
- Updated the dark theme token set so the shared `--background`, `--card`, `--popover`, and sidebar-related variables all use a true black base (`apps/web/src/styles/tokens.css:79-126`). This makes every dark-mode surface start from pure black while keeping existing foreground, accent, and chart colors intact.

Consider running `npm run web:dev` to preview the new contrast and tweak secondary tones if needed.

payload.text:
**Verifying comprehensive dark theme changes**

I’m double-checking that the dark theme uses black backgrounds everywhere, including accent backgrounds and variant theme colors. There are `.dark[data-theme-color=...]` selectors setting primary and accent colors but not background, so I’m making sure `--card`, `--popover`, and sidebar backgrounds all match the user’s request for pure black in dark mode before I confirm the changes.

payload.message: Dark theme surfaces now start from true black—`--background`, `--card`, `--popover`, and sidebar tokens all switch to `hsl(0 0% 0%)` while keeping existing foreground and accent colors (`apps/web/src/styles/tokens.css:79-126`). No additional commands were needed; consider previewing via `npm run web:dev` to ensure the new contrast feels right.

summary.text:
**Verifying comprehensive dark theme changes**

I’m double-checking that the dark theme uses black backgrounds everywhere, including accent backgrounds and variant theme colors. There are `.dark[data-theme-color=...]` selectors setting primary and accent colors but not background, so I’m making sure `--card`, `--popover`, and sidebar backgrounds all match the user’s request for pure black in dark mode before I confirm the changes.

content.text: Dark theme surfaces now start from true black—`--background`, `--card`, `--popover`, and sidebar tokens all switch to `hsl(0 0% 0%)` while keeping existing foreground and accent colors (`apps/web/src/styles/tokens.css:79-126`). No additional commands were needed; consider previewing via `npm run web:dev` to ensure the new contrast feels right.
